oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: Welcome to the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: Item 2, then, this morning is a post-legislative scrutiny session on the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: I'm very pleased to welcome Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, who is director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: As I've said, it's a bit difficult to place myself in the mind of the previous Minister when this legislation was first envisaged and then taken through.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But we have to have legislation now that is fit for the circumstances we currently find ourselves in and, hopefully, futureproofs us for how we want to see the sector develop in the future.

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: Do you believe that the Act has fulfilled all the Government's objectives?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: You'll be aware that there were four main reasons for the introduction of the Bill: around regulation of institutions in Wales; safeguarding the contribution made to public good arising from Welsh Government's financial support for the sector; maintaining a focus on fair access; and preserving and protecting the principle of institutional autonomy.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think the evidence that has been received by the committee to date shows that there are different views about the effectiveness of whether all four strategic aims have been achieved.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there is a very clear expectation that the commission will have, in regulating the sector, and co-ordinating and funding the sector, to create a system of outcome agreements, where those outputs will reflect national priorities, and that's one of the things that we've consulted on, and will look to take forward in the new legislation.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, in order for their courses to be specifically designated, the three crucial questions that those providers have to answer are: quality—is what they’re providing to students of a good quality; the financial viability of the institution, again, to try to protect the interests of the students who may find themselves embarking on a course in an institution that isn’t viable; as well as their contribution to private—sorry, not to private good—public good.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Personally, I wholeheartedly believe that tertiary education providers should contribute to national goals and outcomes as part of what I'd describe as a civic mission.

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: The Act, or the Act as it stands, makes it a requirement for a regulated institution to be a charity, and that means it's not possible to regulate alternative private providers under the Act, even though they can provide higher education in Wales.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: We received substantial evidence from HEFCW suggesting that powers were inflexible and hard to use—I think HEFCW called them 'threatening'—saying that they make sanctions difficult to use and so on.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, looking ahead to the new Bill, I would want to see and be very keen to ensure that there are sufficiently flexible—did you use the word soft—and soft regulatory powers that the commission could exercise.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, I would expect the commission to be able to have a series of abilities to intervene, from the soft, flexible type, which is non-punitive but actually allows people to go in and support institutions, through to something that would be, as I said, more punitive, if they felt that an institution was in danger of not providing quality or financial failure.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: I'll move on to managing risk, if that's okay.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, certainly transnational education does present real opportunities for Welsh institutions, but if not managed appropriately and regulated appropriately can cause real risks to reputation to our sector.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the advantage of the Act?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: As I've said, it's a bit difficult to place myself in the mind of the previous Minister when this legislation was first envisaged and then taken through.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: You'll be aware that there were four main reasons for the introduction of the Bill: around regulation of institutions in Wales; safeguarding the contribution made to public good arising from Welsh Government's financial support for the sector; maintaining a focus on fair access; and preserving and protecting the principle of institutional autonomy.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think those strategic aims are still really, really important and certainly will underpin our thought process going forward, but we have to recognise the higher education and research Bill across the border in England, the implementation of new student support measures in Wales, as well as the report that was done by Ellen Hazelkorn, I think, means it is appropriate that we move forward with different proposals, not just regulation of the HE sector but the post-compulsory sector as a whole.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: What is really important, and what we will be seeking to do in the new legislation, is look to move to a system of outcome agreements.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there is a very clear expectation that the commission will have, in regulating the sector, and co-ordinating and funding the sector, to create a system of outcome agreements, where those outputs will reflect national priorities, and that's one of the things that we've consulted on, and will look to take forward in the new legislation.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the weakness of the Act?

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: Do you feel perhaps that the legislation itself hasn't been strong enough, and that you then have had to drive some of these objectives through the annual remit letter, rather than through legislation, and that's why the strengthening is required?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Certainly, I see the remit letter as a really, really important way in which national priorities and the priorities of an elected Government can be clearly stated, communicated to the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, and then HEFCW use their powers to ensure that that happens.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, I think, first of all, it's important to make the distinction between the scale of private providers, and what could be termed as 'unregulated providers' in the Welsh system, as opposed to the English system.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, currently, under the current legislation, unregulated providers can only access Welsh Government student support if they're designated on a case-by-case basis.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, in order for their courses to be specifically designated, the three crucial questions that those providers have to answer are: quality—is what they’re providing to students of a good quality; the financial viability of the institution, again, to try to protect the interests of the students who may find themselves embarking on a course in an institution that isn’t viable; as well as their contribution to private—sorry, not to private good—public good.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I have to say that, at present, we've not identified an urgent reason to designate these courses as qualifying courses for the purposes of a fee limit.

specific_query_list.query: What had the Act and the Bill already achieved?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Of course, the funding situation has shifted again now because of the introduction of what is commonly known as the Diamond reforms, but our new system of student finance does again shift the parameters of influence that HEFCW or any new tertiary commission could have.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We've been able to successfully see all institutions sign up to becoming living wage employers, all institutions sign up to the Welsh Government's code of ethical procurement.

specific_query_list.query: How could the Act and the Bill be improved?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, I've just talked about living wage; we're also using our remit letter to drive transparency over senior leaders' pay, the gender pay gap within institutions.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: For instance, as part of this Government's commitment to improving mental health, we've been able to use the remit letter and some funding to be able to drive change and some improvements in mental health in the higher education sector.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: That's one of the reasons why we are going to introduce the new PCET reforms—to create collaboration, not just between different higher education institutes but actually across the sector.

specific_query_list.query: What was the current situation about HEFCW's powers of intervention?

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: They explained to us that they often take informal measures or actions in their role as regulator, and they've explained that the small size of the sector enables good relationships to be developed.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, I would expect the commission to be able to have a series of abilities to intervene, from the soft, flexible type, which is non-punitive but actually allows people to go in and support institutions, through to something that would be, as I said, more punitive, if they felt that an institution was in danger of not providing quality or financial failure.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: We use those mechanisms and informal interactions with FE college principals, with the work-based learning provider network, with sixth forms and others, and we would want to see, I hope, in the tertiary sector some alignment of those things.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: When things go badly wrong, there are a range of mechanisms.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: I think what stands behind HEFCW's comments is that before we had a loan-based system of student finance, there was a system of block grant allocations and conditions could be attached to those grant allocations by HEFCW.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting talk about to control HEFCW's powers of intervention?

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: In the Hazelkorn review, there's quite a lot of focus on that and looking to learn from other national systems where outcome agreements provide a broader measure of the range of things the institutions do and a mechanism for tracking how things are done through the provision of information back to the institution to help them know how they're doing.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there's that balance to be struck, isn't there, about creating a regulatory regime, which I'm very keen and the Act attempted to do, which was to enshrine institutional autonomy, and that's really, really important, but also a regulatory regime, the ability to influence and to develop and to deliver national outcomes and the power to intervene in that sector, which you know, better than probably anybody else in this room, guards that institutional autonomy very, very, very dear indeed.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: I think, in terms of the levels of measures—and I understand what you're saying—but I think what HEFCW were saying was that they try as far as possible to use informal measures and they are able to do that because of the size of the sector—just 10 institutions to work with.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: So, the informal measures might not be as prevalent as they are currently, possibly.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Yes, but also, what's incumbent upon me as the Minister is to ensure that the commission is set up in a way where it can have that relationship with the sector, because what's really important to remember is that HEFCW will be replaced.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: If they were to do that because a university was breaking fee limits or because there were real questions about the quality of the provision or whether a university was not complying with the financial management code—personally, I wouldn't describe those as minor matters, as a Minister, if we had an institution that was significantly falling down on quality and HEFCW were using these powers to intervene.

specific_query_list.query: What did Hefin David AM concern about the fee and access plans?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think, certainly, to really understand the success of the fee and access plan, you have to question whether an annual basis is an appropriate timescale for a university to be working to, and whether we could have something that was focused over a longer period of time.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: In a way, it's difficult to make a final judgment on whether fee and access plans in their current format have worked, because we need to know what'll happen to those students in the future.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But undoubtedly, despite the limitations of them, I do think we're making progress in terms of access, but I don't think we can necessarily point to the fee and access plans as being the driver for some of those improvements.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Oh my goodness me, civil servants in the department are constantly in discussion with a range of stakeholders as we continue to develop legislative proposals.

specific_query_list.query: How did Kirsty Williams AM plan to manage risks?

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: The feedback from Universities Wales suggests that, with the outcome of the 2015 Act, institutions with the strongest track records are more highly regulated than the riskier private alternative providers.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: Do you think that Act has struck the right balance?

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: So, I think we need to be careful in focusing on the inherent quality of things.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: We've made charitable status a key reference point in the operation of things at the moment.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: I think there has been attention drawn to some private providers, particularly in England, but I wouldn't tar them all with the same brush, necessarily.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, we would regulate them on a course-by-course basis, so it's back to the issue of proportionality, isn't it?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: And as Huw said, I think we should recognise the nature of that is very, very, very small in Wales, and there is a process to ensure quality provision.

specific_query_list.query: What did Kirsty Williams AM react in response to concerns of the governance of universities?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, I think it's true and fair to say that the Bill does not directly address issues around governance in the sector.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: The first is, as I just said to Hefin, I have sought to have a more direct relationship with chairs of universities and have that one-to-one relationship with them, not in the presence of their vice-chancellors.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: And I think it's really important that parties have come together to recognise the issues and to agree to take action, because I think if we'd have tried to impose something, we'd have more resistance.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Of course, in individual institutions, it does vary, but I think there is some way to go to making sure that our governing bodies are diverse and that there's an opportunity to look at the student voice in governance going forward, the staff voice in governance going forward, and these are things that we hope to have discussions on whilst we bring the legislation forward.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: And I believe—I'll need to check this—that there are plans to engage with each of the governing bodies, because, as you rightly say, and this lies behind a lot of what we've been discussing, the activities of these institutions have become much more complex over recent years, and so there is a need for that training and development and understanding also of the fast-changing nature of that activity.

specific_query_list.query: How did Sian Gwenllian AM ask about the quality assurance?

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: We've heard evidence regarding the difficulties caused by HEFCW having a legal duty to quality-assure all the provision in two further education colleges.

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: That sounds to me like some kind of an anomaly or an unintended consequence of the Act.

oracle_info.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
oracle_info.content: Could you clarify that and explain the situation in that instance?

specific_query_list.query: How did Kirsty Williams AM answer Sian Gwenllian AM's question about quality assurance?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: My understanding—and as I said, it's a bit difficult, because I can't put myself into the thought process of the Minister at the time and what his expectation was.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But, certainly, my understanding is that it was not an unintended consequence, it was an expectation built into the Act that HEFCW and Estyn would work together on these matters.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: The Act built on what were the quality assessment arrangements in the 1992 Act, which required HEFCW to secure arrangements for the assessment of the quality of education provided by funding institutions.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, as a consequence of that approach, HEFCW's quality assessment duty currently encompasses all the education provided by or on behalf of a regulated institution.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: There's a lot of joint operation.

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: We're looking to the new Bill to try to make that clearer.

specific_query_list.query: What did Kirsty Williams AM say about her plan for quality assurance?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I am aware, and we've listened to stakeholders' concerns regarding proposals to introduce a single quality assessment body.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: As I said, I don't want to pre-empt bringing forward the legislation, but the principles underlying any assurance regime would need to be coherent, need to be effective and need to be comprehensive.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: What we're also very clear about, and I think it is important to say, is that any quality framework covering higher education will be compatible with ENQA, which I think is really, really important going forward.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: And by an extension of that, it would be compatible with current UK-wide baseline standards.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, we don't want to create specific problems for the HE sector in Wales.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, sometimes, I think it is necessary, maybe, to cause a stir.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: If we don't change things, it does beg the point of, 'Why are any of us here if we're not here to sometimes move things forward?'

oracle_info.speaker: Huw Morris
oracle_info.content: So, I think we're not looking to impose one institution on anybody, but we are looking to encourage greater synergy in the ways in which quality assurance and enhancement is undertaken in those different areas of activity.
